title: 111_hr3737
content:
The "Small Business Microlending Expansion Act of 2009" allows intermediaries to report borrower information to credit agencies for credit building. It also provides flexibility in credit terms. SEC. 3. FLEXIBLE CREDIT TERMS. Amends the Small Business Act to remove "short-term" from certain paragraphs. SEC. 4. INCREASED PROGRAM PARTICIPATION. Section 7(m)(2) of the Small Business Act is amended to require experience in making microloans and providing assistance to small businesses. The Small Business Act now requires experience in making microloans and providing intensive marketing, management, and technical assistance to borrowers. SEC. 5 increases the limit on intermediary borrowing from $750,000 to $1,000,000 and from $3,500,000 to $7,000,000, with the possibility of treating it as $10,000,000 if deemed appropriate by the Administrator. SEC. 6 expands borrower education assistance by increasing the percentage from 25% to 35%. SEC. 7 introduces the Young Entrepreneurs Program. Section 7(m)(4) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a Young Entrepreneurs Program, allowing intermediaries to provide technical assistance to young entrepreneurs in establishing small businesses and acquiring financing. The Young Entrepreneurs Program allows intermediaries to provide technical assistance to individuals aged 25 or younger who have resided in the area for at least 2 years. Young entrepreneurs who receive assistance must make a good faith effort to establish or operate their small business in the same geographic area. The Young Entrepreneurs Program allows intermediaries to provide technical assistance to individuals aged 25 or younger who have resided in the area for at least 2 years. If a small business concern established or operated by a young entrepreneur receives a loan under this program, repayment can be deferred for up to 6 months. SEC. 8. INTEREST RATES AND LOAN SIZE amended to increase loan size from $7,500 to $10,000 in various paragraphs. SEC. 9. REPORTING REQUIREMENT. Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a reporting requirement for the microloan program. The Administrator must submit a report to the House and Senate Committees on Small Business, detailing the names and locations of intermediaries receiving funds, loan and grant amounts, contributions from non-Federal sources, and the number and amounts of microloans made by each intermediary. The report required under the amended Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act must include details on contributions from non-Federal sources, the number and amounts of microloans made by each intermediary to various groups such as women, low-income, veteran, disabled, and minority entrepreneurs. Additionally, it should describe the marketing, management, and technical assistance provided by intermediaries to borrowers, including women entrepreneurs and business owners. The report required under the amended Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act must include details on contributions from non-Federal sources, microloans made to different groups, job creation, repayment history, and business success after receiving microloans. SEC. 10. Surplus interest rate subsidy for businesses. The Administrator can make grants to intermediaries to reduce interest rates for borrowers receiving financing under this subsection. SEC. 11. Authorization of appropriations. SEC. 11. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2010 and 2011 totaling $200 million for technical assistance grants, direct loans, and interest assistance grants under section 7(m) of the Small Business Act. SEC. 12. REGULATIONS.

The Administrator must issue regulations within 180 days of the enactment of this Act to carry out its provisions. Passed the House of Representatives on November 7, 2009.
